title: (x) Type terminology question - flourishes, ornaments {Mark S}
content: WELL,opps....ok well I'm new to Typophile. Now that that is over I want to know what the little decorative swirls and floral that are put around letters. I couldnt figure out how to post a picture so I hope everyone understands what I mean. Are they a form of font. Theyre usually on or around elegant words. If anyone gets what I'm talking about, could you help me, I just have a great interest in learning how to do them well.
author: muffinmanbrander

comments.content: Daliance by Emigre is a good font to look at. Lots of font enhancements

Flourishes maybe, swashes no, engrossing no. Ok not the stuff that attaches to the type but the decorations around it. ![sorta like this](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023145434im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69441.jpg) i just did an ugly quick one, Stuff like that ^^^^.

Ornament? Ornamentation? Filigree?   
   
(I'm putting question marks after all my suggestions because I'm not exactly sure what the proper name for this is, whether there is one, or if I understand precisely what you are referring to. Still, one of them might fit.)
I apologize, I'm searching each example, thanks for everyhting.

Fleuron would answer some of the question   
 [http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=fleurons](http://web.archive.org/web/20131023145434/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=fleurons), generally I would refer to these marks as ornaments.   
Tim
